story: NewsChampagne's French heritage overwritten as expert claims it was pioneered by English cider-makers in the West CountryOrigins of fizzy tipple have been rewritten by an expert who says English made first sugar additions "with the intention of making the liquid bubbly"Share&nbsp&nbspCommentsByNada Farhoud22:06, 30 JUL 2018Updated22:07, 30 JUL 2018NewsChampagne, French? Mais, non, claims an expert in the field of champagne history (Image: Getty)Get daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailFrench winemakers should be toasting the English...for without them there would be no champagne as we know it. Techniques to make the famous sparkling wine were actually developed by cider-makers in the West Country, who also made perry from pears, an expert claims. Dom P&eacuterignon, a Benedictine monk, is usually credited with developing the secondary fermentation used to make champagne. But in Bursting Bubbles, Robert Walters writes: “The method was presented by Christopher Merret to the Royal Society in 1662, at least 30 years before [its use] in the Champagne region.  “The English were first to make sugar additions to all sorts of still wines and ciders with the intention of making the liquid bubbly.” His book also explains how the French, who then began to make wines with a fizz, struggled with exploding bottles.

title: chef gets subtle revenge party
story: NewsChef gets subtle revenge on party of rude customers - can you spot it?Anton Lofthouse, 34, decided revenge was a dish best served cold after the insulting behaviourShare&nbspByDavid Keane11:54, 30 JUL 2018Updated13:14, 30 JUL 2018NewsThere was something amiss about the desserts the customers received (Image: Kennedy News and Media)Get daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA cheeky chef decided revenge is a dish best served cold after a rude party of customers acted in an insulting way. Anton Lofthouse, 34, made all their ice cream deserts into the shape of a PENIS. He is head chef at a south London pub and had a large party of 60 pre-booked for a three course meal last week. But he was fuming when they turned up more than an hour-and-a-half late and did not apologise. The chef, originally from Middlesbrough, playfully arranged the two scoops of ice cream together and then squirted on the chocolate sauce in a sausage shape - creating a phallic shape for those looking carefully. Despite his cheeky stunt being spotted by colleagues while serving, it appeared to go unnoticed by the customers who ate it without complaint.  Anton, who has been head chef at the unnamed venue for seven months, said: A large party of 60 people were booked in. When such a large group are booked in we can't serve food to anyone else so had to close to the general public. We only have a tiny kitchen and there was only myself in there so three courses for 60 people is a massive job for one person. But they turned up an hour and a half late and offered no apologies or anything like that and they were a bit of a nightmare. So I decided to have a bit of fun. They had asked for ice cream and stipulated that they wanted it in a big bowl rather than the small tubs we traditionally serve them in. But in a big bowl there is a lot of space left and obviously they also wanted chocolate sauce on it.

title: couple took baby five hour
story: NewsCouple took their baby on five-hour boozing session and fed infant Wotsits as they got drunkSiobhan Blackhurst and Damon Gilbert's child had a dirty nappy and food was stuck on its face, hands and in its hairShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByWendy Barlow19:55, 30 JUL 2018Updated22:04, 30 JUL 2018NewsSiobhan Blackhurst and Damon Gilbert took their baby to the pub (Image: MEN MEDIA)Get daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA couple took their baby on a hair of the dog boozing session and fed the infant Wotsits as they got drunk, a court heard. Siobhan Blackhurst and Damon Gilbert were still feeling the effects of a heavy party at their home the night before and decided to go out to drink it off. Dad-of-five Gilbert, 31, pushed the 16-month-old child home in a pram after a five-hour drinking spree in a beer garden, but was so intoxicated he was staggering and could barely open his eyes. The youngster, who almost fell out of the pushchair, was filthy, hadn't had a nappy change and was was taken off Gilbert by neighbours, who called the cops.  Police found the child's mum Blackhurst, 29, still drinking two hours after Gilbert left the pub. The pair's house in nearby Colne reeked of alcohol and was littered with bottles, the court heard. Gilbert said he had downed lager and Sambuca the night before and told a probation officer he had still been drunk. Magistrates in Burnley heard Blackhurst, who claimed the child had been properly looked after throughout the day, put the tot's state down to the fact the infant had been eating Wotsits and was covered in them. The couple, who are both jobless, on benefits, and have alcohol problems, were spared jail after the Bench said they needed support. Gilbert and Blackhurst, who have been together six years, were said to have stopped drinking since the incident and had referred themselves for treatment. Philippa White, prosecuting, told the hearing the defendants were pushing the child past the Market Tavern, on Market Street, Colne, at around 11am, when the landlady was opening up the premises.  She heard Gilbert say: Should we go in here for one?  The prosecutor said: They went in the premises and remained there the rest of the afternoon, until around 4pm. They were drinking most of that time in the beer garden. The child was with them at all times. Mrs White said about 4pm, the landlady was concerned about how drunk Gilbert was and suggested he should go home. He left in a highly intoxicated state with the child in a pram and Blackhurst stayed in the pub. Gilbert made his way back to their home and knocked on some neighbours' door.

story: NewsDramatic change in UK weather prompts possible U-turn on hosepipe ban by water companiesBosses were planning a hosepipe ban for early August but the deluge of rain that hit the country over the weekend has left everything up in the airShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByPaul Byrne22:09, 30 JUL 2018NewsThe hosepipe ban was thrown into disarray by a sudden bout of bad weather in the UK (Image: PA)Get daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailWater chiefs are about to decide if next week’s hosepipe ban should be scrapped. River and reservoir levels are being examined in the wake of the deluge that hit large parts of the UK over the weekend. Some places had more rain in a few hours than the average for the entire month. But the heatwave is expected to make a blistering return this week. And experts fear the downpours were not have enough to prevent hosepipes and sprinklers being switched off in the North West on Sunday.  United Utilities, the UK’s largest water supplier with seven million customers, was the only firm to announce a restriction. Such a move would reduce water usage by 5% to 10% or 100 million litres per day. The firm has been criticised for a &pound180million dividend to shareholders while losing a quarter of its supply through leaks – said to be enough to fill 175 Olympic-sized pools daily.  United Utilities said: “A large team will be looking at our resources following the rainfall. “There is a lot of that data to get through. In terms of the hosepipe ban, that has not changed, as yet. “It is possible it might once we have all the data.”

title: durex recalls real feel latex
story: NewsDurex recalls Real Feel and latex-free condoms over fears they could SPLITThe products sold in the UK and Ireland were failing to pass its "stringent" shelf-life tests, according to the companyShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByLaura Forsyth20:56, 30 JUL 2018NewsTen batches with expiry dates between December 2020 and February 2021 have been recalledGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailDurex has recalled some batches of its condoms over fears they could split. Ten batches with expiry dates between December 2020 and February 2021 have been recalled. Durex said: Our condoms are intended to provide a method of contraception and prevent the transmission of sexually transmitted infections (STIs) through a non-latex barrier that offers a benefit to consumers sensitive to latex. It referred customers to the product's warning label advising them to seek advice from a doctor or pharmacist as soon as possible and no later than 72 hours if a condom leaks or bursts during use.

title: englands most unequal town life
story: NewsEngland's 'most unequal town' where life expectancy is the same as EthiopiaStockton-on-Tees, in County Durham, is the town with England's largest gap in health and life expectancy, according to Public Heath EnglandShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByAbigail O'Leary09:45, 30 JUL 2018Updated11:11, 30 JUL 2018NewsThe father-of-eight suffers from emphysema, lymphedema and type 2 diabetes - among other conditions (Image: BBC)Get daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailIt is the town where being born just two miles apart could give you 18 more years of life. The shocking life expectancy gap in Stockton-on-Tees, in County Durham, is laid bare in a BBC documentary highlighting the desperation of those facing ill health and death from a comparatively early age. According to Public Health England, Stockton is the town with the country's largest gap in health and life expectancy.  A man can expect to live to 64, the same age as a man in Ethiopia. Rob Hill, a father of eight, tells interviewers that he is preparing for death at 46 after being diagnosed with numerous health problems. He suffers from emphysema, lymphedema and type 2 diabetes - among other health conditions.  Rob claims poor life choices, including an unhealthy diet and a lifetime of smoking, has left him with a bleak future. Speaking to BBC's Panorama , Rob said: I've made a few bad choices. Smoking - the worst choice I ever made in my life. Seeing my kids cry, that's horrible. Seeing them sitting there and crying and listening to my children turn around and say, 'my dad is going to die soon and I'm not going to play with him any more'. Rob's eight-year-old son Harvey told the investigative programme: When dad comes into the kitchen, I just see him coughing all the time.  And then I just end up going away. I don't stay in the kitchen. I don't know, like no-one ever knows when he's going to be gone. No one does, not even the doctor. Rob goes on to describe how his younger children are used to playing with him while he is hooked up to breathing apparatus at home. In his hometown, those living in wealthier areas can live 18 years longer than those living in poorer parts of the town, according to national statistics. While nationwide, a boy born in a wealthy part of England could expect to live over eight years longer than a boy born in a more deprived part of the country.

title: five men tried smuggle more
story: NewsMen 'tried to smuggle £40million of cocaine on private jet after pretending to be meeting Bruno Mars'Alessandro Iembo, Martin Neil and Franco-Lorenzo allegedly paid £128,500 in cash to hire a private jet as they pretended to be cryptocurrency leaders on their way to meet the singer in Colombia last DecemberShare&nbspByNina Massey22:38, 30 JUL 2018NewsFarnborough Airport (stock image) (Image: Universal Images Group Editorial)Get daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThree men charged with smuggling millions of pounds of cocaine into the UK posed as music industry clients on a trip to meet Bruno Mars, a court has heard. Alessandro Iembo, 28, Martin Neil and Franco-Lorenzo, 40, allegedly paid &pound128,500 in cash to hire a private jet as they pretended to be cryptocurrency leaders on their way to meet the singer in Colombia last December. The three men, alongside Neil's brother Stephen Neil, 53 and Jose Ramon Miguelez-Botas, 56, are charged with prohibition in relation to a class A controlled drug after border force agents stopped them on a second flight from Bogota in January. When booking the private jet for the earlier trip, the woman who paid the man who ran Diamonte Jets - a chartered jet service provider - gave him &pound128,500 in cash for three passengers. Prosecuting Kerry Maylin told jurors: She said they were leaders in the field of cryptocurrency, they were involved in the music industry and that her clients would be meeting Bruno Mars in Colombia. Subsequent checks revealed the singer had been in the South American country at that time.  As part of the booking, it was also asked that a luxury chauffeur driven Rolls-Royce Phantom car collect the men upon their return to Farnborough. It was to take them to an address in Bromley, south east London. Jurors heard when the three men returned to the UK on December 11, they landed with a number of suitcases but it cannot be said for certain what was in the luggage as they were not stopped. Prosecutors claim the group hid drugs in a suitcase underneath dirty children's clothes when they were caught.  They were arrested in January at Farnborough Airport in Hampshire after allegedly flying in from the South American country's capital of Bogota. In the dock at Woolwich Crown Court are brothers Stephen Neil, 53, and Martin Neil, 49, both from Poole, Dorset. They deny one count of fraudulent evasion of a prohibition in relation to a class A controlled drug, between October 30 2017 and January 30 2018.

title: mums tongue rebuilt muscle skin
story: NewsMum's tongue rebuilt with muscle and skin from her ARM after she was struck down by cancerous ulcerLiuz Marsh underwent 14-hour life-saving op in which surgeons removed a third of her tongue and used skin, muscle arteries and veins from her arm to repair itShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByMartin Fricker20:27, 30 JUL 2018NewsBrave Liz Marsh had part of her arm fused with her tongue after discovering an ulcer in her mouth had turned cancerous (Image: Caters News Agency)Get daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA young mum had her tongue rebuilt using muscle and skin from her arm after being struck down with a deadly cancerous ulcer. Liz Marsh, 28, became of the one of the youngest patients in the UK to be diagnosed with mouth cancer after the ulcer on her tongue tripled in size in the space of four weeks. She underwent urgent life-saving surgery to remove the growth and surgeons also had to cut off a third of her tongue. During the same 14-hour operation they used skin, muscle arteries and veins taken from her arm to rebuild the muscular organ.  Brave Liz, is now cancer free but has had to learn to talk, eat and smile again. She said: “I was shocked when surgeons explained that skin, muscle, veins and nerves from my arm would rebuild my tongue. “When I first spotted the ulcer in my mouth I thought nothing of it. “But when it started to become painful and grew, I raised my concerns to my dentist.  “They told me to come back in four weeks and after visiting my doctor, it was dismissed as being a harmless ulcer. “My son, Charlie, now two, had undergone heart surgery at the time and we all thought it was stress related. “But my dentist referred me for tests and a few weeks later I had a biopsy. “I was told just over a week later that I had mouth cancer, by which point the ulcer had turned black.  “Thankfully my consultant at Princess Royal Hospital in Telford was amazing and he reassured me that I could be fixed. “I had a lot of muscle and veins removed from my arm so they could help rebuild my tongue. “It was a complex surgery but I was out of hospital 11 days later. I had been fed through a tube for the entire time I was in hospital and I had to try and relearn to eat once I left.  “For months after my surgery I struggled to smile as my mouth felt numb but now I’m embracing my imperfections. “I also needed speech and language therapy. It was really swollen for a long time but eventually I started to enjoy eating again.” Liz, from Shrewsbury, Shrops, was initially diagnosed in October 2016 but underwent further surgery in May. She added: “My new tongue was quite bulky so I needed it to be trimmed back once all the swelling had settled.  “I hope being open with my story helps others seek help, if it saves one person’s life then it’s worthwhile. “If you have an ulcer, white patches or a lump in your mouth then make sure you get it checked.” “Doctors were shocked when I was diagnosed as I was so young but it shows it can happen to anyone. “Due to my age I have recovered well from surgery and hopefully I will remain cancer free for the next few years so I’m given the all clear. “I currently have check-ups every eight weeks but this will be extended the longer I’m in remission.

story: NewsWhy Princess Charlotte doesn't have to curtsy to the Queen - even though big brother Prince George has to bowPrincess Charlotte is already proving to be there perfect little princess, but there's one royal rule she doesn't have to followShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByZoe ForseyAudience Writer17:12, 30 JUL 2018Updated17:15, 30 JUL 2018NewsLittle Charlotte is already proving to be the perfect little princess (Image: PA)Get daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe Duke and Duchess of Cambridge's second born Charlotte is only three, but she's already proving she's the perfect princess. Her royal wave is spot on, she's always smiling for the camera and she's even shown off her sassy side to a group of photographers. But she's still got a lot to learn when it comes to being royal, and the life of protocol and rules ahead of her. However there's one thing the little princess, who is fourth in line to the throne, doesn't have to do, even though her big brother Prince George does - bow to the Queen. When asked by Hello! magazine when young royals are expected to start following the tradition, historian Marlene Eilers Koenig said: Certainly by age five.

title: raf corrie mckeague theories questions
story: NewsCorrie McKeague theories and questions - sex apps, the missing £53k and pregnancy riddleThe 23-year-old dad-to-be and RAF man vanished without a trace on a night out 18 months ago, but huge police and private search efforts have failed to find himShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByRussell Myers16:20, 30 JUL 2018Updated16:40, 30 JUL 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay nowGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe father of missing RAF man Corrie McKeague has declared his son is no longer missing and claims he knows what happened to him. His heartbroken dad wrote on Facebook that Corrie was last tracked to near a landfill site and is now somewhere in the Suffolk waste disposal system. The police investigation into his disappearance was shelved by detectives in March. But for many, the mystery of what happened to the 23-year-old is anything but solved. His family accept he was probably crushed and his body left in landfill after climbing into a recycling bin which was later collected by a Biffa lorry. But they blasted the “glaring errors, mistruths and downright lies” reported as fact which plagued the police operation.  Dad Martin, 49, said: “I’ve nothing but praise for the officers who’ve searched tirelessly for Corrie. But the investigation has been plagued with problems. Now I’ll never find exactly what happened to my beloved son.” Mum Nicola has also campaigned tirelessly since Corrie vanished in Bury St Edmunds, Suffolk aged 23 in September 2016. Det Supt Katie Elliott said: “It’s extremely disappointing we haven’t been able to find him.” A cold-case unit will take over, as revealed in the Daily Mirror when we also told how Martin feared his son may have taken his own life. Here are the points left unresolved after the &pound2.15million, 18-month probe. The Biffa lorry blunder  Corrie was seen on CCTV eating some takeaway food at 1.20am before falling asleep in a doorway for two hours. He then woke up and staggered 110 yards to the back of an industrial “horseshoe” area at 3.25am and was never seen again. It is believed he most likely crawled into a large recycling bin before being tragically crushed to death when a Biffa truck collected the cargo 50 minutes later and dropped the contents to a trading depot. Early on in the investigation, a false reading of the load of the bin was given. The contents were recorded as weighing 11kilos, or 1st 10lbs, when it was actually 116 kilos, or 15st 7lbs – a difference of nearly 14st. The false reading led police initially to discount the theory that Corrie was in the bin before the company came forward to correct the error. An independent report has agreed with Suffolk police’s conclusion that Corrie’s remains lie in the landfill site where the rubbish load on the Biffa lorry was taken. The landfill site  The independent report concluded Corrie’s remains lie in the 120-acre landfill site in Milton, Cambs – 30 miles from where Corrie was last seen. Detectives believe the most likely scenario is that the gunner, based at nearby RAF Honington, got into a recycling bin that was scooped up by a Biffa bin lorry from a horseshoe-shaped storage area and taken to the landfill site. Officers last year sifted through nearly 10,000 tonnes of rubbish in 27 weeks of searching at the site, but found no sign of his body. However, police yesterday made the astonishing admission that two separate searches they carried out there may have been in the wrong area of the site. Suffolk police said: “The records relied upon are not comprehensive and lack the detail required to identify precise search areas. Investigative enquiries identified the landfill site areas where Corrie was most likely to be. “This does not rule out the possibility of him being elsewhere within that site, or indeed at another landfill site. “The areas where Corrie could be now, are vast – many times bigger than the area of landfill already searched. “It would take years to complete. The environmental and legal impact of digging up such deep and wide areas of landfill is significant and prohibitive.” Did Corrie McKeague kill himself?      Corrie's dad Martin McKeague claimed the RAF man believed girlfriend April Oliver was &shypregnant before he vanished. He feared this would have “a profound effect” on his son’s mental health. His dad couldn't rule out the possibility of suicide, saying in March: “I just can’t help thinking this would have weighed on him heavily and he may have actually chosen to get in that bin that night knowing what would happen. “It’s as probable as anything else and it makes it no less heartbreaking.” Private eye and the missing &pound53,000  Campaigners blamed police for “lacking basic resources” to handle calls from the public. A JustGiving site set up by local campaigner Cheryl Hickman said: “The police investigation team, through a combination of lack of resources, intransigence and incompetence, have failed to capture and process vital evidence and still lack the basic resources to efficiently process a tiny number of phone calls per week.” Suffolk police categorically denied this but failed to correct continued public statements by campaigners that the police were struggling. More than 5,000 well-wishers raised &pound53,000 – but so far no public accounts have been published, despite promises on the JustGiving site. The money was allegedly used to fund private investigators. But Suffolk police said the private probe created no new lines of enquiry. The private eyes provided a single disk of information relating to the FindCorrie Facebook page. Corrie’s dad Martin said: “I feel sorry for the well-wishers who donated their hard-earned money.” Campaigners’ posters gave five mobile phone numbers “answered by Corrie’s family and friends” instead of the official police hotline. Det Supt Elliott said: “Naturally we’d have wanted the information to come into the investigation team but it wasn’t within our remit to stipulate exactly how that should happen.” The Mirror has attempted to contact Ms Hickman for a comment. The deleted social media accounts including Grindr  Corrie was leading a double life, trawling the internet in search of casual sex with strangers. The 23-year-old gunner had an account on dating website Plenty of Fish. The serviceman described himself as “a princess” who was looking for a relationship. He also had an account on the gay dating app Grindr, set up when he was aged 21, two years before he disappeared. The account carried the username “BiLad21”. Corrie and his girlfriend April Oliver also joined an online swingers’ club. The airman created a profile on the Fab Swingers website in 2014, saying he was looking for straight and lesbian couples as well as for single women aged 18 to 60. It stated: “We are a young couple, but we know what we want.” Corrie’s family believe there could have been vital information in the social media accounts. However, they were deleted before the police were able to contact all relevant parties who may have come into contact with the serviceman. The Mirror can reveal “advice and assistance was offered to Corrie’s mother Nicola, above, around social media” from Suffolk police after it emerged she was responsible for deleting social media profiles. Det Supt Elliott said: “I am not willing to discuss operational details.” The pregnancy riddle

story: NewsRide London marshall in serious condition after being hit by female cyclist near 75-mile markerPolice today appealed to the cyclist, witnesses, or anyone with photos or video footage of the collision at about 11.15am to get in touchShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByKelly-Ann Mills19:11, 30 JUL 2018Updated19:20, 30 JUL 2018NewsThe start of the RideLondon-Surrey 100 event (file) (Image: Velo)Get daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA marshall was left in a serious condition in hospital after being hit by a cyclist during the Ride London event. story: NewsSecret WW2 mission saw garlic smuggled out from Nazi-occupied France for peckish French forces in BritainWhen French forces stationed in Britain became desperate for the taste of their homeland, a pilot was sent out by Special Ops to fetch the stinky cloves of wonderShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByMark Branagan19:40, 30 JUL 2018NewsFarmer Bill Spidy, centre, pictured with his wife, right, in 1944, shortly after he helped grow garlic bulbs for French forces in the operation (Image: Ben Lack Photography Ltd)Get daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA top-secret mission smuggled out sacks of garlic from under the noses of the Nazis so French forces exiled in England could have a taste of home. Some 300 French sailors escaped in 1940 but by 1942 were pining for the cloves, which were virtually unknown over here. When Bill Spidy, landlord of their local the Painters Arms in Cowes, Isle of Wight, heard morale was low he contacted the Special Operations Executive. The spy organisation lined up the garlic mission with 161 Squadron at RAF Tangmere in West Sussex – known as the Cloak and Dagger Squadron.

title: stag reveals truth over claims
story: News'Stag' reveals truth over claims 'homeless man' was paid £90 to get name tattooed on his foreheadJamie Blake claims he woke up after a night out in Benidorm, Spain, to discover shocking pictures online of a man with 'Jamie Blake, North Shields, N28' inked on his faceShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByKali LindsayLucy Clarke-Billings21:30, 30 JUL 2018Updated21:57, 30 JUL 2018NewsMr Blake said Tomek [pictured] is not homeless and was, to his knowledge, not paid (Image: Facebook)Get daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA man has hit back at claims his friends paid a homeless man &pound90 to tattoo his forehead. Jamie Blake claims he woke up after a night out in Benidorm, Spain, to discover shocking pictures online of a man with Jamie Blake, North Shields, N28 inked on his face. The images - which show a Polish man called Tomek smiling and gesturing a peace sign - were quickly deleted after outraged social media users slammed the prank as barbaric. But Mr Blake says he wants to set the record straight.  The 37-year-old claims he had nothing to do with the incident and was not on a stag do, Chronicle Live reports.  He also says the man in the picture isn't even homeless.  Jamie, who said he moved from North Tyneside to Benidorm three months ago, also believes Tomek was not paid any cash to have the tattoo done. He said: I was not there at the time. There was a big group of around 30 of us drinking in the bar. There was a group of Irish lads there as well and Tomek. He isn’t homeless, he lives with my friend and works on the strip. I got drunk and was asked to leave the bar. I was never in the tattoo parlour and as far as I know he was not paid any money. Jamie said he split up with his partner before the incident but still decided to go ahead with a 'stag do' of sorts.

title: stepmum teenager who took photo
story: NewsStepmum of teenager who took photo of disabled woman pelted with flour and eggs insists 'he's not a tearaway'A gang of teenagers in Bury St Edmunds pelted the woman with eggs and flour then posed for a photo around herShare&nbspByTom DavidsonOnline Reporter14:26, 30 JUL 2018Updated15:15, 30 JUL 2018NewsThe photo has sparked widespread outrage (Image: Facebook)Get daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe stepmother of a teenager who took a photo of a disabled woman after his friends pelted her with flour and eggs has insisted he is not a tearaway, according to reports. The Daily Mail say the stepmum of the 17-year-old, who cannot be named for legal reasons, insisted the lad was just a stupid boy. A photo on social media appears to show the teenagers posing behind a cowering woman who had been covered in flour and eggs as she sat on a park bench in Bury St Edmunds, Suffolk. Police have said two 17-year-old boys and two 15-year-old boys have been arrested in connection with the incident and released on bail. The woman, who also is battling mental health problems, is said to have shouted at the bullies before being pelted with the cooking products.   Speaking to the Daily Mail the stepmother of one of the boys, who lives in east London, said: He got caught up in it all, it was a stupid thing to do.  He's never been in any major bother before but this is serious. His dad won't say anything about it because the police have asked him not to but he's upset. I don't know why the lad got involved. As far as I know he just took the photo. I don't know anything about him throwing the eggs and flour. Suffolk Police Inspector Anthony Bridgland said: This type of behaviour is totally unacceptable and we are treating the matter seriously. We know this incident may have caused concern and anger both in the local community and online, but we would like to reassure everyone that we are tackling the matter robustly and supporting the victim.  The woman was severely distressed but not physically injured, Suffolk Police said. A friend of the victim, Katherine Brame, said the woman was safe, writing on Facebook: I have to speak out. Today’s incident has made me so sad and devastated. The lady in question needs her privacy and suffers with an unseen illness. She cannot cope with people popping in, or gifts. It’s complicated but if you want to help, how about donating to a mental health charity as people with these unseen illnesses go under the radar all the time and they are totally under-funded. Then maybe she will get the real help she needs from qualified people. You’re all very kind.

title: woman two teenagers found unresponsive
story: NewsWoman and two teenagers found unresponsive at Huddersfield house after contact with 'illegal substance'Police have opened an investigation after three people fell ill at a three-bed semi-detached house in Skelmanthorpe on Sunday eveningShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByLucy Clarke-Billings17:33, 30 JUL 2018NewsEmergency services were called to the scene shortly after 7pm yesterday evening (Image: Huddersfield Examiner/MEN Media)Get daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA woman and two teenagers were rushed to hospital after coming into contact with an illegal substance last night. Police have opened an investigation after the three people fell ill at a house in Skelmanthorpe, Huddersfield. Emergency services were called shortly after 7pm and a 40-year-old woman, 40, along with two boys aged 14 and 16, were found unresponsive at the scene. All three were taken to hospital where they continued to be treated today. Cops said they may have unknowingly come into contact with a potential illegal substance in the household. Neighbours said two teenage boys were unconscious in the driveway before police were called to the property.  The two boys looked like they had been beaten up as they lay slumped outside the three-bed semi-detached home on Sunday evening. A neighbour, an elderly woman in her 60s, said: I don't know the full story, but a mum and her two sons live at the property. Another neighbour who lives around the corner said he two of the young lads just laid out in front of the drive. It was like they looked like they had been beaten up. Then all this today comes out as if they had taken some type of drugs or substance. This is a nice area, but anything goes on nowadays.  The neighbour said the community had been left shocked following the heavy emergency service presence last night. One police car remains at the property with forensics combing the home for evidence. I just couldn't believe - you don't normally see six ambulance vehicles at one property, added the neighbour. Dean Jackson, 49, who lives on a street close by, said: I came past the house going home just as a paramedic car, a Skoda Octavia, put its lights on behind me. A bit later my mate who lives just down from the house came round to mine to watch the boxing and said he saw two blokes laying out in front of the house and emergency services all around. Judith Faulding, who lives in one of the neighbouring houses, said she has been told nothing by police other than one officer confirming one of the teenage boys was doing okay.

story: NewsMan 'who used Tinder to find victim he murdered may have killed others in crime spree'Danueal Drayton, 27, was found by police holding a woman against her will in her flat, where he was arrestedShare&nbspByLaura Forsyth23:32, 30 JUL 2018Updated23:35, 30 JUL 2018NewsDanueal Drayton is a suspect in murder and rape cases used dating websites to find victims, police say (Image: DCPI)Get daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA man suspected of murdering women he met on the dating app Tinder may have killed others, according to police. Danueal Drayton, 27, from Connecticut was arrested last week in Los Angeles and charged with attempted murder. Investigators said he sexually assaulted a woman, tried to strangle her and refused to let her out of her North Hollywood flat. Officials added that after he was arrested, he spoke about killing at least five other women in Connecticut and New York. Police are still trying to confirm whether his claims are valid, reports CNN.  While police believe that Drayton did not admit murdering Samantha Stewart, a nurse found dead in her New York City flat they do believe he is responsible Her body was discovered on the floor of her bedroom in Queens wrapped in blankets on July 17. It appeared that she had been strangled and a number of her teeth had been knocked out, according to police. The pair met through Tinder and following the murder then used her credit card to pay for a flight to California. He was then found by police in Los Angeles holding a woman against her will in her flat, where he was arrested. Drayton has also been connected to the rape of a 23-year-old in Brooklyn on June 17 after they met on Tinder.

title: girls powerful message man who
story: NewsGirl's powerful message to man who made 'sexist' comment about her friends is inspiring women around the worldA 12-year-old Girl Scout has being hailed a "feminist icon" after publicly calling out an adult over a sexist remark made about her friendsShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByCourtney Pochin16:58, 30 JUL 2018NewsJulianne stood up for her friends after a man made a 'very sexist' remark about Girl ScoutsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailSexism is an issue that affects people of all ages. Young girls, for example, are often being told that they shouldn't play certain games, or should act more feminine - and many simply do as instructed. However one Girl Scout from a small town in Ohio refused to let a sexist comment slide. Julianne Speyer had been taking part in the Chesterland 4th of July parade with fellow Girl Scouts and Boy Scouts. All had been going well until the person announcing the parade informed the crowd that the Boy Scouts were the future leaders of America and that the Girl Scouts were  just having fun.  The 12-year-old was really bothered by this comment, so she decided to take action and wrote a letter to the editor of her local paper, the Geauga Maple Leaf, to highlight the issue. Her letter, which has gone viral on social media, said: My name is Julianne Speyer. I am 12 years old and I would like to inform you of how offended and disappointed I am by the announcer of the Chesterland 4 July parade's comment about the Girl Scouts and Boy Scouts. Julianne wrote that she found the comment to be very sexist and patronising. She added: I would appreciate it if you would help me to let other people know how much this kind of thing happens and how bad it is.  I feel it is an insult to both girls and women of all ages. This kind of thing happens way too much and it is not OK at all. “I have always been taught that if you think something is unjust, change it. So this is how I am making a change. Thank you for listening to me and I hope you can help me.” People on Twitter went wild for her letter, with more than 17,000 people sharing it and 62,000 people liking it. One person said: This girl for president!

title: dundee boss neil excited about new signing kharl madianga
story: Dundee boss Neil McCann was delighted to see practice pay off at a key moment in the 2-0 Betfred Cup win at Peterhead.With the scores locked at 0-0 against a disciplined Blue Toon line-up, the Dark Blues eventually made their dominance count after half-time as new signing Kharl Madianga rattled in his first goal for the club.Joining the play late, the 24-year-old arrived on the edge of the area, created space for the shot before smashing past the goalkeeper.And gaffer Neil says that late arrival is something the team worked hard on in the pre-season training camp in Portugal.He was also delighted to see one of his new boys get off the mark in a Dundee shirt – especially after an extended time off the park due to an off-field dispute with his former club, Lokomotiv GO.Neil said: “Sunday was Kharl Madianga’s first game in a year and I asked him the last time he scored – I don’t think he could remember!“He’s got loads to offer. From a player who hasn’t played for a year you can see he can get about the pitch and he’s only going to get better.“I’m quite excited about him and I’m pleased he got on the scoresheet.“That opened it up because Peterhead worked really hard to try and limit us chances.“We’ve been working on that actually over in Portugal, midfielders coming from deeper positions into that area and he finished it well, too.“It was a comfortable finish, he didn’t rush it, though he did with one later in the game.“The over-riding feeling is we’re quite pleased to come away with three points because we were quite disappointed on Sunday.”Dundee went on to seal the three points in stoppage time as another new face found the net as Jean Mendy made it two goals in three games.Neil added: “I was pleased, clearly Peterhead were going to make it difficult.“They dropped everyone right off the ball and sometimes had 11 players in the last 40 yards of the pitch. That denies us space and it was difficult.“However, I thought we were patient enough and scored two really good goals.“We created a lot. I’m pleased because I know how difficult it is going to Peterhead. I’m just happy to go home winning the game because it was a difficult match.”

title: dundee linked with croatian striker
story: Dundee are set to hand a week-long trial to Croatian striker Stipe Plazibat ahead of the league campaign kicking off at St Mirren on Saturday.The 28-year-old has spent the last two years plying his trade in Singapore with Home United, scoring 37 goals in 39 games.The 6ft 1in hitman is in line to spend the next few days training with Neil McCann’s side as the club look to make their sixth signing of the summer.With Marcus Haber exiting the Dark Blues to join Falkirk on a season-long loan and Sofien Moussa on the physio’s table, if Plazibat makes the grade he could fill a space in the squad.If the Croatian front man impresses he could find himself in the travelling party to face St Mirren in the Premiership curtain-raiser at the Simple Digital Arena on Saturday afternoon.

title: dundee people all aboard thehms unicornfor family fun
story: Swashbuckling pirates stormed the HMS Unicorn as people of all ages turned out for the vessel’s summer family fun day.Youngsters dressed up and got the chance to meet unofficial mascot Pirate Bob.Children also had their faces painted and took part in sand art activities.There was even a special curator’s tour of the Music of Maritime Life.Billy Rough, education officer at the Unicorn, said: “It was such a fantastic day.“It was incredibly busy despite it being a glorious sunny day. We were delighted to have live music courtesy of Big Noise Douglas and a motley crew of pirates from Medieval Methil Re-enactment Society entertained families.“Pirate Bob was, of course, on hand to entertain kids with lots of pirate games.“Look out for our next family fun day in October.”The next fun day will take place on October 20.

title: dundee people cheers to the newly wed beers as lisa and lewis tie the knot
story: It was cheers to the Beers as loved-up couple Lewis Beer and Lisa Mordente partied all night long after they tied the knot.Lewis, 33, and Lisa, 28, first met in a very different kind of aisle when they started working together at Tesco Riverside in 2009.For their first date they went to Laing’s Bar and from then on their romance blossomed.“After that date we were with each other all the time,” said Lisa, a maths teacher.“Lewis kept me waiting seven years before finally proposing – I think he was getting a lot of hassle from people to get it done.”When clinical trial co-ordinator Lewis finally did pop the question, it was the private proposal Lisa had always wanted.“It was the morning of my birthday and I was in the house getting ready for work,” she said.“Lewis handed me a birthday card and when I opened it the front said ‘to my fiancee’ and he had drawn a big question mark inside.“By the time I turned back around he was down on one knee.“I didn’t want a big showy thing so I was quite happy it was in the house.“I think Lewis knew that though – I had given him enough hints.”On her wedding day, Lisa woke up in the beautiful country mansion Balmuirfield House, surrounded by bridesmaids Mechelle McCafferty, Emma Kidd, Jennifer Dunn and Isabella Burns.She was cool, calm and collected while she was dolled up and slipped into her stunning white gown.However, as soon as her dad Godfrey turned up, the normally restrained Lisa turned into a much more emotional version of herself.She said: “I don’t know what happened to me. As soon as my dad walked in, I just felt like I was going to burst into tears at any point.“I had to have a tissue in my hand when I got married just in case.“I am not usually emotional but that day I just kept on crying.”Waiting at West Park Hotel was Lewis with best man Ryan Bruce and ushers James Simpson, Gavin Smith and Euan McCafferty and Lisa’s nephews Ellis and Luis Mordente who were an usher and page boy respectively.By her dad’s side, Lisa was piped down the aisle to the tune of Highland Cathedral.It’s not unusual for Godfrey to be seen at weddings as he is a well-known Dundee photographer.Lisa said: “It was amazing having my dad walk me down the aisle and then he became the photographer for the day too.“Because my dad has been doing wedding photography for so long he knew a contact for every part of our big day so that made it a bit easier.“All of the suppliers were amazing and I can’t thank them enough for helping put our wedding together.”After, the pair, who live near Tannadice Park, said “I do” the evening reception got into full swing.Local band Pepper Pot got everyone up on the dance floor, which is exactly what the bride had dreamed of.“I didn’t want a boring wedding – I wanted everyone to get up and have a good time,” she said.“I first saw the band at my sixth year dance and always said I wanted them to play at my wedding as they were such good fun. Luckily, my dad knew them too.“They played our first dance song Somewhere Over the Rainbow on a ukelele, which was lovely.“Ever since, people have been telling us that it was the best wedding they have ever been to and I have to agree.“I wouldn’t change a thing about the day – it went absolutely perfectly.“I am so happy to be married and want to thank everyone for all they did to make our wedding the best day ever.”

title: dundee people fans dress to impress for 80s rewind
story: It was fun in the sun all the way for the thousands of 1980s fans who enjoyed a bumper weekend of music at Rewind Scotland.As temperatures at Scone Palace soared to the mid 20s the hits of the decade just kept coming.The spectacle kicked off with the Skids on Saturday afternoon followed by a raft of stars including Bob Geldof and his Boomtown Rats, Bonnie Tyler, UB40 and Midge Ure before headline act Status Quo rounded the weekend off in true headbanging style.And as ever the Scottish crowd didn’t let the side down with plenty of neon lycra on show and hundreds of wacky outfits in keeping with the event.

title: dundee people gymnasts take a successful tumble
story: A number of local gymnasts enjoyed success at the NDP British Championships in Nottingham.Five members of Dundee Gymnastics Club 2K travelled to the championships which saw them tumbling down a 25-metre track giving a display of back flips, somersaults and other gravity-defying skills.Earlier last month saw seven of the clubs tumble squad head to Birmingham to represent Scotland in the NDP British semi-finals.Five of these gymnasts qualified, for of those returning with medals. Summer Geddes and Bethany Moss missing out on qualification but an amazing achievement to represent their country.First up to compete was little Katie Robb at NDP level 3 age 9-10, who improved her runs from the semi-finals to bag herself a silver medal.Next up was Lucy Stein who came a commendable 7th in NDP level 3 age 13+.The following day saw Sandy Robb, brother of Katie achieving the gold at NDP level 5 age 10-12 and hot on his heels was another club tumbler winning silver at the same level.Tegan Gaffney was last to compete at NDP level 5 age 15+. She didn’t disappoint bringing home a Bronze medal.Paul Carson, tumbling coach at the club, said: “The gymnasts had to show their speed, power and control when performing their routines. “I am proud as punch of what the team has achieved – it’s really fantastic.”

title: dundee people love at first sight and 60 years of marriage based on trust and happiness
story: Sixty years, 21,900 days, 525,000 hours.Last Thursday, these figures signified the length of time since Dundee couple Jim and Isabella Martin were married.Jim and Isabella Martin had been married.They first met at Camperdown Park in 1953 when Jim was 20 and Isabella was just 18.Isabella describes that chance encounter as “love at first sight”.“I was on a walk round Camperdown Park and Jim was there playing football with his friends,” she said.“The ball came rolling over and landed at my feet. When I saw Jim coming over, my heart was booming.“From then on our love flourished.”Five years later, after Jim proposed in Dublin, the happy couple were married at the High Kirk in Dundee on July 19 1958.In preparation for the big day, Jim lost a stone in weight, which he claims was due to all the worry.Isabella looked stunning in a white lace ballerina-style dress which she says still has “tomato stains down the front”.Jim and Isabella went on to have two sons and a daughter, and 10 grandchildren have followed.Isabella said: “Family has always been first and foremost in our life and to this day we still have a close bond with our family.“We enjoy cruises and have travelled the world, with our children occasionally joining us.”Sixty years is a long time but Jim and Isabella say the secret behind how long they have stayed together so long is very easy.“Our marriage has been based on love, trust and happiness,” said Isabella.“The problem with couples these days is that they just don’t trust each other.“For us it was love at first sight and to this day we still care so much about each other.”The Martins will be celebrating their anniversary with friends and family at Invercarse Hotel next week.

title: dundee people scarlett has her gold and silver ticket
story: A business in jewellery is the golden (and silver) ticket for a happy career for Scarlett Erskine.She started her business – Scarlett Erskine Jewellery – in 2013 after falling in love with the craft during her first year of study at Duncan of Jordanstone.She said: “I did the general course at the university which gave you a chance to get a taster of courses that you could go on to do in the following years.“I tried textiles and jewellery but really enjoyed the craft of jewellery making so went on to study that for three years.“When I graduated I didn’t know how to go about creating my own business.“I visited Vanilla Ink Jewellery School, which was then based in Dundee, for guidance on how to turn my jewellery making into a business.”Now after five years based at Wasps Studio, Scarlett is still creating exquisitely designed pieces and also teaching others how to do it too.Scarlett added: “There are three main parts to my job. The first is my collections of jewellery which I design and make to be distributed to the shops that stock my designs up and down the country.“The second is my bespoke pieces.“This is where someone comes in with a design in mind or with a piece they want to be remodelled.“With my bespoke designs it is much more fun as I can be a bit more creative.“It can be a big responsibility as a lot of the time someone is grieving over the loss of a loved one and they want a piece to remember them by or they want a piece of their loved one’s jewellery reworked.“You can’t change it back, so it can be quite nerve-racking.“I have also incorporated people ashes into designs, so it can be a very emotional journey with my customer.“It is lovely that I can really help customers after the passing of a loved one with a piece that is incredibly sentimental.“The third part is teaching.“I have held workshops since the beginning. I think it makes the pieces more sentimental when someone has made the ring themselves.”After taking the plunge to work on her business full time only a year ago, Scarlett has urged anyone else in the same position to take that leap into self employment.“This business is my life and I love it. It is hard and scary to take that step but I am so glad I did it. I can really put my heart and soul into my pieces now.“I should have done it way sooner.”Scarlett’s workshops allow couples to have a personal touch at their wedding.A growing number of couples are visiting her studios to create their wedding rings – and some of those ready to get down on one knee are even coming to create a bespoke engagement ring for their other half.Scarlett said: “The workshops are incredibly popular and weddings are becoming a lot more DIY with couples wanting to be more hands on.“I love being part of the love story of making their rings.“We also hold hen parties a lot and brides love to come in and make matching silver rings with their bridesmaids.“It is a lot of fun.”

title: dundee people solicitors move up at law firm
story: Scottish law firm Thorntons has promoted 11 solicitors this month.Two have been promoted to associates and nine have been made senior solicitors across the Dundee, Fife, Perth, Angus and Edinburgh offices.The two new associates are Lynne MacIntyre and Stuart Mackie, and the senior solicitors are Steven Drake, Joanne Clancy, Lynsay McFarlane, Thomas Redpath, Neil Falconer, Megan Sweeney, Chris Gardiner and Anneli Spence.Chairman Colin Graham said: “Training and development is a core part of our growth strategy.”

title: dundee people spar customers raise cash for good causes
story: The Spar store on Ballindean Road in the Douglas area of Dundee has been raising funds for a number of local good causes, including Brown Street Kennels, The Crescent in Whitfield and seven-year-old Garvie Winter, who is being treated for leukaemia.Kirsty Laing, from the store, said: “We do quite a lot of different things in the shop to raise money.“We sell a lot of books, mostly for 50p, which are really popular and we also get a lot of little things from customers who want to sell them to raise funds too. We have also held raffles in store.“We don’t focus on one charity but we like to give money to local causes.“We recently donated £50 to Garvie Winter and we have also worked with soldiers’ charities.“It is great to do what we can to help local people and we always take suggestions from our customers for charities to donate to.”

title: dundee united complete loemba deal and vastic could be next
story: Dundee United have completed the signing of winger Yannick Loemba on a two-year deal.The Congolese attacker is Csaba Laszlo’s 12th signing of the summer and, with the arrival of Austrian trialist Toni Vastic yesterday, No 13 might not be far away.Loemba, 28, joins up after a career in his adopted homeland Belgium, which was followed by a brief spell in Turkey last season with Adana Demirspor.And his new gaffer believes he will add an alternative to the options he already has in the attacking third.“Yannick can offer something different to the players already here. He has fantastic pace and loves to run at defences. He is strong on both feet, and I believe he will excite our fans,” said Csaba.After an unsuccessful spell in the Turkish second tier, Loemba is keen to get going in Scottish football.“I am happy to be with Dundee United, I am excited to play in Scotland and want to bring joy to our fans,” he said.Vastic comes in as United look to complete the final part of their rebuilding process since the end of last season.While Csaba is pleased to have secured the services of strikers Nicky Clark and Craig Curran earlier in the summer, he wants more height in his attack. At well over six feet, the former Blackburn and Bayern Munich kid fits the bill on that score.And, over the next few days, the coaching staff will see if he is up to scratch in terms of his all-round striking ability.

title: dundee united duo face fitness checks ahead of elgin city clash
story: Craig Curran and Callum Booth will face fitness checks before Csaba Laszlo decides his line-up for Dundee United’s Betfred Cup trip to Elgin today.Injury means the pair, regarded as among the most significant of the Tangerines’ summer signings, have hardly been seen in the games played so far.Curran’s only public appearance to date was in the friendly at Brechin earlier this month and he’s been struggling to shake off a dead leg.But Csaba remains hopeful he’ll be ready for next week’s Championship opener with Dunfermline.And, if he’s fit enough to manage 45 minutes at Borough Briggs, it would be a major step in the right direction.Booth, meanwhile, took a knock in the defeat at Ross County last week and that ruled him out of the home tie against Alloa.While the former Partick Thistle full-back’s condition is not causing concern, United would like him to get another game under his belt before the league.In line for debuts could be latest recruits Paul Watson and Yannik Loemba.Watson, who arrived from Falkirk last week, is likely to partner Frederic Frans at the heart of the defence, while wide man Loemba is could be on the wing.Having not played since the turn of the year, the 28-year-old is likely to need a few weeks to get his fitness up to scratch.With qualification out reach for both, all that’s at stake today is avoiding the wooden spoon.Csaba sees this as vital preparation for next week.“Especially before the season begins, I say always this is the most important game for the confidence, just to win,” said Csaba.“You do and you know you can score goals.”

title: dundee woman tracey arrives in germany for life saving treatment after incredible 100k fundraising drive
story: Dundee woman Tracey Burke has arrived in Germany as she prepares for the treatment she hopes will save her life.She travelled to the continent after an “incredible” fundraising drive which saw Dundonians raise more than £100,000 in six weeks to fund the trip to a clinic near Stuttgart for cancer treatment.Tracey, from Ardler, was given the devastating diagnosis in 2015.She and husband Greg were busy planning their wedding and looking forward to a lifetime together when she was diagnosed with cervical cancer aged just 27.She was given chemotherapy, radiotherapy and brachytherapy – a form of radiotherapy where a sealed radiation source is placed inside or next to the area requiring treatment – but that didn’t cure her and the cancer spread.Greg set up a fundraising drive on May 13 to raise cash to send Tracey for immunotherapy, after she was told all other treatment options available from the NHS had been explored.He said: “We had hoped to be over earlier but we had a setback with Tracey having to spend time in Ninewells. In some ways it felt like it was taking forever for us to get there. But she is a bit better now so we are really excited and hopeful.“She is still in a bit of pain but hopefully that is OK while we are in Germany. She was back and forward from Ninewells a few times but she’s feeling back to herself now.“It’s strange because all the fundraising was ongoing and that was quite surreal but in some ways it didn’t seem real that we would actually be going.”Tracey said: “I just want to thank everyone who has helped make this possible. It’s just been incredible how everyone rallied together to raise this amount of money so quickly.”The therapy at the clinic in the Black Forest offers immunotherapy, a new treatment that is said to have cured some cancer patients. The treatment uses the body’s own immune system to fight cancer by helping it to recognise and attack dangerous cells.Greg added: “I think the people of Dundee should be really proud of themselves.“It’s a testament to them and their generosity.”

title: gulls mug pensioner for her tuna sandwich
story: A pensioner has spoken of her horror after she was “mugged” by a flock of gulls in the city centre.Patricia Simpson, 69, from Charleston, had been enjoying an afternoon of shopping with her daughter Hazel and grandchildren.The former chef described the incident as like something out of the Alfred Hitchcock horror film The Birds.Patricia was leaving the Overgate near Boots when as many as five gulls swooped on her to snatch her tuna sandwich.She said: “I thought I was being mugged.“One of the gulls drew blood from my right hand.“During the incident I actually thought someone was after my handbag.”Patricia added: “There was no warning – they literally came out of nowhere.“They were right in my face. I’m just lucky they didn’t go for my eyes.“I’ve read the stories in the paper recently and you never think it’s going to be you that gets attacked. I was left shaken by the incident.”Hazel said the drama had put the family off eating in the city centre.She said: “There was one gull at my mum’s head, one at her hand and another one grabbing the sandwich.“We’ve recently returned from Holland and the gulls there are half the size of ours. It is like they are on steroids here.“They’ve got a different temperament in Dundee.“When I heard my mum screaming, I thought she had been mugged as she was walking a bit behind me.”Patricia added: “The whole experience has put me off eating anything in the city centre.“Part of the problem is that people are voluntarily feeding these gulls. I’ve seen it myself.“They should be fined for deliberately dropping food or being spotted feeding them.”A Dundee City Council spokesman said: “We know that gulls can often be a cause for considerable distress and annoyance and we continually pursue tried and tested as well as innovative solutions to the problems that arise from these birds.“We would also ask that people do not feed seagulls as this exacerbates the problem.”

title: ten minutes each game has cost us says dundee united boss csaba
story: Csaba Laszlo believes 10 minutes per game has been the difference between success and failure in Dundee United’s Betfred Cup campaign.That’s why the Tangerines are heading for Elgin on Saturday for what is a dead rubber.However, he’s seen enough from his team in the other 240 minutes of their group games to remain confident a successful league campaign lies ahead.“Unfortunately, a football match is 90 minutes. If we’d played 80 minutes we are the winners,” he said.“It sounds stupid but true. Against Arbroath, after 82 minutes if we put the ball out we keep one zero but we don’t and lose a goal.“In the next game (Ross County), for 80 minutes we made a good game and if we score from our penalty we win. We don’t score from the penalty, then they score and win but we had played a good game.“Then we controlled the game against Alloa but lost a goal, again in the last 10 minutes. So people say we are a bad team. We are not and not everything has been bad.”While he’s confident United will show that in the months ahead, Csaba doesn’t hide his frustration over being out of the Betfred.“We created pressure for the club, for the management, for the players and from the fans.“And we lost a lot of money, let’s be honest. So, I am really unhappy, but I can’t turn this back.“We have to do better. When we have 10 minutes to go and we are in the front, we have to win the game.”Any pressure the past three games has put on him does not, he’s stressed, match the pressure he puts on himself for every outing.“I always have pressure because when we lose I think why did we. For me, there is always the pressure that this is not OK. I think about it all the time and we have to find the solution tactically.”For the manager, that solution lies in getting the right mix between the passing style he prefers and a more direct Scottish approach.“Some people tell me I play too much continental football, we have to play Scottish football, kick the ball more off the front.“We’ll mix, keep the ball down and try to kick the long ball as well but just the long balls won’t be enough.“With Craig Curran injured we have had to use Paul McMullan as a No 9, up beside Nicky Clark sometimes. Paul is more of a winger and we cannot give him high balls and expect him to win headers.”

title: van driver was more than twice speed limit near dundee school
story: A man who drove at more than twice the speed limit near a Dundee secondary school had sentence deferred.Douglas Blyth, 53, of Selkirk Gardens, admitted driving at 41mph in a 20mph zone on Berwick Drive, near Braeview Academy in Whitfield.The offence occurred on May 4 while Blyth was driving his van.Sentence was deferred until August 14.

title: xplore dundee running a special ninewells shuttle bus during roadworks
story: Local bus firm Xplore Dundee is running a special 22c shuttle bus to keep patients, visitors and staff connected with Ninewells during the forthcoming closure of Charleston Drive.One of the busiest roads in the city, Charleston Drive is undergoing essential resurfacing work between Earn Crescent and Lochay Place from Monday August 6 to Friday August 24.Xplore Dundee managing director Christine McGlasson said: “We realise it’s vitally important to make sure that people can still get to the hospital throughout these roadworks and we’re trying to ensure we maintain the highest level of service possible in this area, despite the disruption to the road network.”The shuttle will provide a clockwise loop around Menzieshill every 12 minutes and connect with service 22 on Glamis Road at Balgay Cemetery.Meanwhile, service 17 will be diverted via Dickson Avenue and will terminate at The Shand.Service 22 will be diverted via Ninewells Avenue in order to maintain access to Ninewells Hospital.And from August 11, service 29 will be diverted via the Technology Park to maintain access to the hospital.Regular tickets such as DaySavers can still be used on the 22c, while max single fares will cover the transfer to the 22.Further information is available at the Xplore Dundee Travel Centre.
